In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

Certainly! You can write a function in Julia to perform this cleaning task on the column names as follows:

```julia
function clean_column(col::String)
    cleaned_col = lowercase(col)          # Lowercase the entire string
    cleaned_col = strip(cleaned_col)      # Strip leading and trailing whitespaces
    cleaned_col = replace(cleaned_col, r"[ -]+" => "_")  # Replace spaces and hyphens with underscores
    return cleaned_col
end

# Example usage:
col_name = " My Column-Name "
cleaned_name = clean_column(col_name)
println(cleaned_name) # Should print "my_column_name"
```

This function first converts the entire `col` string to lowercase, then strips any spaces from both ends. It uses a regular expression in the `replace` function to find all occurrences of spaces and hyphens (one or more times, indicated by `+`) and replaces them with underscores. The function returns the cleaned column name.
